jeopardy_round: THE NEW YORK TIMES: ARTS & LEISURE
A PRIEST, AN ELEPHANT & EVEL KNIEVEL...
WHAT IS THIS, SOME KIND OF JOKE?

(2, 1).clue: The Times said of these thin young twins, "It isn't the cover of Vogue they seem to seek as much as the cover of Fortune"

(3, 1).clue: On elephants this prehensile body part has an estimated 150,000 muscles

(4, 1).clue: A villainous type of mustache, a la Snidely Whiplash

(5, 1).clue: Alone again at Christmas?  Time for a big mug of this milk, cream, eggs & rum favorite with a nutmeg garnish

(6, 1).clue: From this sitcom:"How's life treating you, Norm?""Like it caught me in bed with his wife"

(2, 2).clue: nytimes.com's "Find a Show" section tells how to get tickets to "Avenue Q" or this masked man musical

(3, 2).clue: Catholic priests administer 7 of these acts, like penance & holy orders

(4, 2).clue: A style of singing in 4-part harmony; you know, as a "quartet"

(5, 2).clue: Running a fever, eh?  Try a "black balsam" of herbs & this liquor, reputed to have cured Catherine the Great

(6, 2).clue: From this '70s radio station sitcom:"As god is my witness, I thought turkeys could fly"

(1, 3).clue: "The Winter of Our Discontent","The Moon is Down"

(2, 3).clue: From an artsbeat blog: The Vivian Girls, rockers from this NYC borough, are "really, really, really cute"

(3, 3).clue: On his "Sky-Cycle" Evel tried to jump a canyon above this river in Idaho in 1974; too bad the parachute opened early

(4, 3).clue: An 11-letter acid derivative used in medicine as a sedative

(5, 3).clue: Caught in the rain, Mac?  How about one of these, the subject of a 1979 No. 1 song by Rupert Holmes

(6, 3).clue: Shatner, on this show:"dennycranelaw.com.  Pictures, bios, hobbies.  I once captained my own spaceship.  Multi-talented"

(1, 4).clue: "The Moon is a Harsh Mistress","Stranger in a Strange Land"

(2, 4).clue: The times headlined its 2007 review of this series' first episode "smoking, drinking, cheating and selling"

(3, 4).clue: On New Year's Eve in 1967 Evel jumped 151 feet over the fountains at this Las Vegas casino; never mind the landing...

(4, 4).clue: A conference between the judge & lawyers out of the hearing of the jury

(5, 4).clue: I can just tell you're sweating for a Lynchburg lemonade, the Lynchburg referring to this brand of whiskey

(6, 4).clue: Chandler, to Ross on this show:"3 failed marriages, 2 illegitimate children... the personal ad writes itself"

(1, 5).clue: "The Joke","The Book of Laughter and Forgetting"

(2, 5).clue: nytimes.com has up-to-date info on this NYC museum of American art, like its exhibition on "artists making photographs"

(3, 5).clue: This priestly class is the highest class in Hinduism

(4, 5).clue: It's a verb meaning to get off a plane or ship

(5, 5).clue: Bad day, huh?  You might need shots of these 2 alcohols made from the agave plant

(6, 5).clue: Steven Culp on this show (after being called Dr. Van de Kamp):"Please, you're dating my wife.  Call me Rex"

(1, 1).clue: Barry Goldwater, in Arizona, which still had this status

(2, 1).clue: It's what the tail does if things are backwards

(3, 1).clue: The first known design of a self-propelled vehicle was made by this artist & scientist around 1478

(4, 1).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew stands at a monument.)  I'm at this country's Monument to the Discoveries, looking at national hero Vasco da Gama

(5, 1).clue: Pairs of these slightly dished metal circular plates have clashed together since Assyrian times

(1, 2).clue: U Thant, in this current country

(2, 2).clue: Who can forget Mena Suvari on a bed of petals in this film? (The title is a type of rose)

(3, 2).clue: Some scientists predict this "seasonal" period of cold & dark weather would be the result of atomic warfare

(4, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew stands at a windmill.)  I'm at a windmill in the city of Woerden in this country

(5, 2).clue: There's a Great Highland type of this musical instrument

(1, 3).clue: This "Streetcar Named Desire" director, in Constantinople

(2, 3).clue: Americans say "the whole enchilada"; Brits say this, a Best Picture Oscar nominee from 1997

(3, 3).clue: Astronomer Michael Brown discovered the object classified as UB313 in 2003 & named it for this TV princess

(4, 3).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew stands in a Spanish city.)  I'm in this Spanish city, the home of the world-famous Running of the Bulls

(5, 3).clue: In "The Music Man", "Seventy-six trombones led the big parade with a hundred and ten" of these "close at hand"

(6, 3).clue: Permission granted to a sailor to go ashore

(1, 4).clue: This film critic & "A Death in the Family" novelist

(2, 4).clue: This 1996 Geena Davis action title can be a euphemism for death (Hint: In the film, she puts her past life to bed)

(3, 4).clue: These radiation belts named for an American physicist are found in the earth's magnetosphere

(4, 4).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew stands at a shrine.)  I'm near Kyoto at the famed Fushimi Inari Shrine, so I'm in the southwestern part of this island

(5, 4).clue: As a verb, this musical instrument means "to dwell upon persistently & tediously"

(1, 5).clue: Andrei Gromyko, the face of the USSR as this minister from 1957 to 1985

(2, 5).clue: Of the 10 targets one bowls at, it's designated No. 5; it also can refer to a person of chief importance

(3, 5).clue: Darwin's younger contemporary, this 3-named scientist evolved a similar 1850s theory of natural selection

(4, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew stands on a verdant mountain peak.)  I'm at this legendary South American site whose name means "old peak"; over there is "new peak"

(5, 5).clue: Comrade, enjoy this 3-stringed Russian instrument with a triangular body & a thin neck

(6, 5).clue: The meaning of the Greek word "atomos" which gives us "atom"

(0, 0).clue: In 1912, midway through one of his works, he wrote, "I have penetrated the secret of the rhythm of spring"
